dt: {bc}the act or process of {a_link|mediating}: such as
{bc}intervention between conflicting parties to promote reconciliation, settlement, or compromise

dt.t: The town feud raged until April … when, with the {wi}mediation{/wi} of William N. Byers the dispute was settled and the name of Denver selected for the settlement.

dt: {bc}a means of resolving disputes outside of the judicial system by voluntary participation in negotiations structured by agreement of the parties and usually conducted under the guidance and supervision of a trained intermediary

dt.t: More couples are considering {wi}mediation{/wi}—or using a mediator to help them reach a compromise—rather than hiring two lawyers who fight it out for their clients.

dt: {bc}indirect conveyance or communication through an intermediary

dt.t: Islam recognizes no ordination, no sacraments, no priestly {wi}mediation{/wi} between the believer and God.

Like any of the other emporiums of the western ocean, Mogadishu had plenty of employment for the commercial brokers … who provided the crucial {wi}mediation{/wi} between the arriving sea merchants and the local wholesalers.

dt: {bc}transmission by an intermediate mechanism or agency

dt.t: The critical role of the hippocampus in the {wi}mediation{/wi} of normal memory processes has been highlighted by the observation that in human patients bilateral damage to the medial temporal lobe, including the hippocampus, produces an extensive and durable amnesia for new information.
